You are totally right. This guy tends to wander in his own thoughts and as time went by, his writings got more and more incoherent. He kept using sentences like "Back then, the girl used to do this and that", "A while ago, I did not use to do this and that", "Back then, my mother/grandmother used to do this and that". I remember there was one time I was reading his book, and within 3 paragraphs, he jumped from present day to the past and to the present day again, then to the past, and then to the present day again good LORD. And within that 3 paragraphs, he had like used his "Back then..." 3-4 times. After that I kind of gave up on him. His writing is no doubt the 'friendliest' Vietnamese lit out there, and can be read by anybody, but my advice would be that you should read his books that were written before 2000.

People love it because it's realistic. A good novel doesn't always have to have perfect characters. If you want perfect and likeable characters that much, you should read "The Notebook". Yes, Ng·∫°n sounds like a loser, H√† Lan must be a utilitarian girl, D≈©ng is an f-boy. But that's why this story could have touched so many people- because it's realistic and it's relatable. We don't need to be gods to love, to hate, to have meaningful memories and bitter experiences. Ng·∫°n, as I said- is just a below-average guy, but his loyal with Ha Lan is a symbol for a type of love that so many people on earth have experienced: the innocent, no self-interest emotions toward your crush, your first love. Sometimes this type of love is harmful to both of the parties, but it's love regardless and that's why Ng·∫°n's emotions toward H√† Lan in this novel should be seen with empathy even they are not sensible at all. H√† Lan can be observed as a typical beautiful girl who changes her environment from rural to urban. Her life can turn in two directions - either to become independent and to be happy, or it can also be very painful. Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh made her make a choice and we should not criticise it, but to learn from her decision's consequences. Furthermore- About D≈©ng, I don't think he's that bad. Yeah, he's pretty bad, but in this novel, he represents the guys who are young and have nothing to worry about life and/or financial problems. Guys like that can be carefree, heartless or to be seen by some people as cruel but it's a fact of life and there is little thing we can do about it other than protecting and improving ourselves. And lastly, Tr√† Long- a cute girl with all the good traits, but turns out to be just a copy or someone else's replacement. It's bitter and it's hard to accept, but again it's realistic. Trust me, if you dive deep enough into love, someday you may find yourself- or your partner just to be a replacement for a ghost of the past. But I hope that you all won't have to live a whole life in that role, and that's what Nguy·ªÖn Nh·∫≠t √Ånh are trying to say with us, by using Ng·∫°n and Tr√† Long.
